item.title: Introduction to Kubernetes: kubectl
item.author: mike@bridgecanada.com (Mike Bridge)
item.description: Over the past few installments, we’ve create a python microservice, dockerized the result, created a Container Registry and Set up the Azure Kubernetes Service. We now have a container serving a flask app to the internet from within a Kubernetes cluster. Let’s try out some Kubernetes features via kubectl.

item.title: Set up Kubernetes on Azure
item.author: mike@bridgecanada.com (Mike Bridge)
item.description: So far in this set of blog posts we’ve created a simple python microservice using flask, added user input validation and then dockerized the result. In Part 4 we’ll set up a Kubernetes Cluster on Azure Kubernetes Service so that we can deploy a preliminary version of the app.
